Text: Congress must ensure the U.S., with NATO and our European partners, is fully equipped to counter Putin and Russia’s warmongering and revanchist ambitions.
It is critically important for Congress to demonstrate, with broad bipartisan support, the U.S. commitment to international law and security, and the independence of the people of Ukraine.

I commend President Biden’s strong and swift response, uniting our NATO allies in combatting the belligerent Russian threat, and I stand ready in Congress to support and bolster these actions to hold Putin accountable.
Putin’s illegal escalation poses the greatest security threat to Europe and the world in decades.

Putin’s theater of lies is fooling no one — sending Russian troops into eastern Ukraine is the beginning of an invasion and a blatant violation of both international law and Ukraine’s sovereignty. The world must respond appropriately.
Putin’s moves in Ukraine are an affront to the democratic will of the Ukrainian people to determine their own future, and a flagrant and dangerous challenge to international law and security.
The security of the United States is inextricably tied to upholding the universal commitment to international law, sovereign borders, and every nation's right to self-governance. 🧵
I’m proud to have helped pass this law and return taxpayer dollars to the Tenth District while doing the work of environmental justice.

Waukegan has for years been neglected and suffered at the hands of irresponsible corporations and former government officials that failed to protect it. Now, we're investing in the health and wellbeing of Waukegan families and returning jobs, tourism, and recreation to the region

The bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act is putting communities like Waukegan front and center. Today, through the bill's funding, the EPA is taking the steps necessary to finish the cleanup of Waukegan Harbor.
https://t.co/QWQT8SEIap

I am proud to have earned a 100 on my @HSLegFund Humane 2021 Report Card. This issue is personal for me: our family dog, Jojo, was rescued from a puppy mill. I will continue to advocate for dogs like JoJo and champion animal welfare issues going forward. https://t.co/oCr6N6EgUS

In Illinois, @LurieChildrens has reported a drastic increase in suicides since the pandemic began. Today on #SaferInternetDay, I'm calling for social media platforms to take down videos that cause damage to kids' mental health. Taking this step is crucial to saving lives.

News today: The Biden Administration announced that Medicare will cover the cost of home COVID tests for our seniors.

This news comes after our letter to HHS asking for these tests on behalf of the countless seniors who called into the office. https://t.co/oVooHLFOxt

As I have since the vaccines were first available, I strongly encourage all who have not yet received the vaccine to get your shots, and if you haven’t yet received your booster, please do so as soon as possible.

Unlike a year ago when I had COVID-19 the first time, this time I will be fighting the virus with the full protections afforded by the vaccine and I am looking forward to a speedy and complete recovery.

I am incredibly grateful for the remarkable efforts of our scientists, medical researchers and all those who worked tirelessly to bring forward the vaccines and treatments that are saving countless lives in the fight against COVID.
I am not presently exhibiting any symptoms, and am able to effectively work from home while isolating this week, as per CDC guidelines and guidance from the House Attending Physician.
Earlier this morning, I had a negative result from a rapid antigen test before a scheduled television studio interview.  Thankfully, I am fully vaccinated and have received a booster shot.
Unfortunately, this evening I had a positive COVID-19 result after proactively taking a rapid antigen test prior to attending a public event.

Black history is American history. This February, we celebrate, remember, and resolve to continue the fight for justice. 

On the Ways and Means Committee, my commitment is to advance our Racial Equity Initiative to promote justice.
#BlackHistoryMonth
It is long-past time for the United Nations to end its long-standing bias against Israel.

We look forward to working with the Admin to end this one-sided COI and reform the Human Rights Council, including through the institution of membership standards and the removal of the standing agenda item on Israel, the only country-specific agenda item.
However, we must not stop there.

This is unquestionably just another attempt by the United Nations Human Rights Council to unjustifiably target Israel. The Biden Administration has rightly stood with our ally Israel, opposed this COI, and worked to minimize its impact.

Set up in May 2021 just days after the conflict with Hamas, the COI ignores Hamas’ terror activities preceding and during the May conflict, and instead attempts to discredit Israel by focusing on “root causes” of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Together with my colleagues @RepTedDeutch @RepDWStweets @RepKManning @RepElaineLuria @RepJoshG @RepDeanPhillips @RepLoisFrankel, we are pushing back against another attempt by the UN to unjustifiably target Israel.

I am deeply disappointed and frustrated by the recent UN General Assembly vote to approve resources for an unprecedented, open-ended Commission of Inquiry (COI) to investigate Israel. 🧵https://t.co/AwKAYzg4Pp
Congress should swiftly pass the Israel Relations Normalization Act to support the Abraham Accords and help bring more sounds of peace to all the nations, and the peoples in the region.

Israeli President Isaac Herzog made an official visit to the United Arab Emirates, including talks with Abu Dhabi Crown Prince Sheikh Mohammed bin Zayed Al Nahyan.  Hatikvah was played, and President Herzog aptly noted “that’s what peace between nations sounds like.” https://t.co/M3Vocoi0ej

As we mark the 49th anniversary of Roe v. Wade, the right to access safe and legal abortions is under attack. We cannot go back to a time when women did not have the freedom to make their own healthcare decisions.

Illinois has 2,374 bridges in poor condition. That’s why Congress passed the largest federal investment in bridge repair in history: to ease traffic and improve safety for every driver in Illinois and across the country. 

https://t.co/KuLfl4gyBJ

The average IL driver pays $609 per year in costs resulting from driving on roads and bridges that need to be repaired. By sending $1.4 billion to IL for bridge rehabilitation, the bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act is going to bring costs down statewide.

Today, our nation honors the life of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. 

Dr. King once said, "Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere." I hope our nation carries this lesson forward as we continue the fight for voting rights and racial justice for all Americans.

Two things Congress can do immediately: (1) help Jewish institutions afford security enhancements, and (2) move forward on the appointment of Deborah Lipstadt as US Envoy to Combat and Monitor Antisemitism.

The American white nationalist who murdered 11 worshipers at the Tree of Life Synagogue and the British national who held 4 worshipers captive at Congregation Beth Israel shared nothing in common—nothing but their choice to attack and terrorize Jews.
The answers to all these questions are rooted in the simple reality of antisemitism.
Why do so many question the legitimacy of a Jewish state in the birthplace of the Jewish faith and the homeland of the Jewish people?
Why do synagogues across the US, and around the world, require extra security, every single day?  Why are Jews warned when traveling to hide any public displays of their faith?
Perhaps the question is not so much why did this one attacker chose a synagogue but why, irrespective of grievance, attacks disproportionately target synagogues and Jews?
The Beth Israel hostage taker flew from Britain and specifically selected a synagogue and held captive four Jews who were there for Shabbat prayer services.
While relieved that the synagogue attack in Texas ended with the safe rescue of the hostages, we must remain steadfastly vigilant in the fight against antisemitism here and around the world. 🧵

Grateful that all hostages at Congregation Beth Israel in Texas are safe.  Thankful for the the first responders, SWAT teams and FBI. No American should have to fear for their safety in their house of worship. We must always stand against hate. 

https://t.co/AYFh9Ym2GB

We didn't let the insurrection and seizure of the Capitol stop us from doing what we needed to do. The most important message in Jan. 6 was that the Constitution held, that the elected representatives completed their task that day. https://t.co/8kEtb9qq7N

The fact that so much remains unknown about those responsible for the day’s carnage only underscores the importance of the work of the Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the United States Capitol.
The deaths of Kevin Greeson, Benjamin Phillips, Rosanne Boyland, and Ashli Babbitt were all tragic, and wholly avoidable.
Responsibility for the blood shed and lives lost on January 6th lies firmly in the hands of the rally’s organizers.
Their absence is keenly felt by their family and friends; their memories will forever be a blessing for our nation.

more than 140 officers were injured, Officer Brian Sicknick died following the violence, and Officers Howard Liebengood, Jeffrey Smith, Kyle DeFreytag, and Gunther Hashida were all lost to suicide. Each of them bravely defended the Capitol.
Let us also always remember that our survival last January 6th did not come without costs. The U.S. Capitol Police and D.C. Metro Police suffered a terrible burden in defending the Capitol:

To secure faith in our elections, I urge the Senate to pass the Freedom to Vote Act. To combat rising extremism, I urge my colleagues to pass the bipartisan Domestic Terrorism Prevention Act introduced last year with my Senate colleague Dick Durbin.

If we want to continue pursuing the American experiment, fundamentally, every American today should be working to ensure that every ballot can be cast safely, that it will be counted fairly, and that the outcome of our elections will reflect the true will of the people.
There are no guarantees that our nation will persist as the kind of representative democracy our founders envisioned 250 years ago.

But we must also recognize that, one year later,  many of the underlying causes of the tragedy of January 6th remain – including continued disinformation campaigns, hyperpartisanship, and emboldened extremists willing to circumvent our electoral system.
We rightly celebrate the victory of democracy over violence last year.

Despite the siege of the Capitol, the insurrection, orchestrated by some at our government’s highest levels, failed at the end of the day, Congress completed its constitutional duties and two weeks later we witnessed a peaceful transition of power to a new administration.

From escaping  the House Gallery as a violent crowd tried to break through the chamber doors to defiantly returning later that evening to fulfill our job and certify the count of electoral ballots, the day for me represented the steely resilience of our democratic institutions.
January 6th is a day seared into my memory.

I am proud to be a member of the bipartisan Problem Solvers and proud of my work with my GOP colleague @RepAGonzalez to offer paid leave to parents who have lost a child. Thanks to our work together, and President Biden’s signature today, it is now the law of the land.

The Big Lie and the January 6 Insurrection are at the center of attacks on our democracy and our constitution.  We must stand strong against those who seek to undermine our government and still reach across the aisle to do the peoples’ work. 

https://t.co/5kuT5JlRRG

The international community, through the United Nations resolution, prohibits Iran from taking any action with respect to ballistic missiles designed to be capable of delivering nuclear weapons – including launches using ballistic missile technology.

No one man gets to decide when we give up on these causes. I will never give up on this work. And I pray that Senator Manchin can find a way to not give up here either. 

Even if today our differences may temporarily feel unbridgeable, we are a strong nation and will persevere.

The Build Back Better Act will lift up our nation and directly address these challenges by lowering the cost of prescription drugs, building our clean energy economy and lifting children out of poverty. All while easing inflationary pressures and being 100% paid-for.

We cannot let the vagaries of any one Senator, nor the intransigence of extremists, stand in the way of our meeting the challenges confronting our nation.  From a breaking health care system, to a rapidly warming climate, to our children’s future, we stand at the crossroads.

I came to Congress nearly a decade ago to improve the lives of the people I represent. We cannot afford to chase dreams of castles built in the clouds. Nor can we afford to throw up our hands when things are hard.
Congress must find a way to come to the table and get to ‘yes’ if we ever want to unite the country and improve the lives of all Americans—from Illinois to West Virginia.

This week, I traveled across my district. In every gathering I attend, I hear the same two things: ‘we have challenges with the supply chain, and we desperately need employees. We have a hard time hiring people.’ 

Immigration reform is an important solution.

They can't put enough caretakers in the rooms taking care of the beds, providing the therapy and in their occupational therapy rooms. They know that simple solutions on immigration policy would help their business and would help our seniors.
Despite raising their pay, offering to provide education stipends, they simply can't find enough people to care for their patients.

Just yesterday, I visited a rehabilitation and long term care facility. They care for seniors in need, whether it's long-term or after surgery, and they're looking for nurses, therapists, other critical health care workers, to literally help patients get back on their feet.

America needs results on immigration. 

We can't afford to leave our immigrant community hanging. We can't afford to leave our businesses hanging.  I hope my colleagues in the Senate will make their own determination on their body’s rules and include immigration reform in BBBA. https://t.co/nmVECaQKAo

on our communities. We discussed the need to rebuild public trust in the agency’s work to combat the harmful effects of EtO through stronger EPA engagement with impacted communities, especially environmental justice communities like Waukegan...

Finally, this bill restores the State and Local Tax (SALT) Deduction for millions of middle class families

Makes the largest investment in affordable housing in history
Extends the expanded Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) for around 17 million low-wage workers

ECONOMY AND JOBS:
Expands access to affordable, high-quality education beyond high school: increasing the Pell Grant and helping more people access training at community and technical colleges to fill high-wage job openings.

HEALTH CARE:
Reduces prescription drug costs: Allows Medicare to negotiate drug prices
Strengthens the Affordable Care Act and reduces premiums for 9 million Americans
Expands Medicare to cover hearing benefits

CHILDREN:
Enacts Universal Pre-k
Saves Americans more than half of their spending on child care
Extends the American Rescue Plan’s expanded Child Tax Credit, cutting taxes for working families and lifting millions of kids out of poverty

CLIMATE CHANGE:
Invests $555 billion in fighting climate change and well-paying jobs, the largest ever single investment in our clean energy future. This includes my bills to decarbonize aviation and strengthen domestic clean energy supply chains.
I have said from the start that I want a bill that will address four things: climate change, children and education, health care, and economic growth.  This legislation robustly checks every box:

I could not be more proud and excited about the wonderful investments this law will bring to our great state.

The new law will also invest in our clean energy future, helping to fund the construction of a robust electric vehicle charging network across the state, while also making the single biggest federal investment in our history towards climate resiliency.
Sewage and flooding improvements will be funded across flood-prone communities such as the Fox River, Des Plaines River, and the North Branch Chicago River Watersheds.
Illinois will receive more than $1.7 billion for clean water and lead water line replacement in towns like North Chicago and Waukegan, and many others.
The new law will provide Illinois with $4 billion to improve public transportation options, transforming everything from projects like our Metra system to the Pace bus routes across our district.
With the Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act, Illinois will receive more than $11 billion for road and bridge repair projects like improvements to east-west traffic along Illinois Route 120.
For years, our state has struggled with what has generously been evaluated to be C-grade infrastructure – and that’s only after grade inflation.
I know that this law will be a boon for Illinois.
I am deeply grateful to the President for his leadership on this issue and his determination to have a law that would get broad bipartisan support from across Congress and the United States.

From broken roads, bridges, and rails, to crumbling sewage, broadband, and water pipes, Democrats and Republicans have joined together to affirm the commitment that we will win the twenty-first century with modern infrastructure and good-paying jobs.
Today, the United States takes a giant step forward on investing in our future with the bipartisan Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act. https://t.co/7TMR8WAbsJ
